title: 108_s2889
content:
The Act is titled the "American Bald Eagle Recovery and National Emblem Commemorative Coin Act". The bald eagle, designated as the national emblem of the United States in 1782, symbolizes freedom, democracy, and American values. It is unique to North America and is prominently featured in the Great Seal of the United States and various government seals. The bald eagle, symbolizing freedom and American values, has influenced various aspects of American culture since the nation's founding. It was once endangered but is now gradually recovering in the US. The bald eagle was listed as an endangered species in 1973 under the Endangered Species Act, later upgraded to threatened status in 1995. Efforts from various agencies and organizations led to the initial recovery of the bald eagle population in the US. The administration is expected to delist the bald eagle from both endangered and threatened species lists by 2008, emphasizing the need for continued care and protection of the species and its habitat for full recovery and survival. The bald eagle nests in 49 States will require continual monitoring after being removed from the Endangered Species Act in 2008, necessitating substantial funding due to budget cuts. Congress wishes to offer the opportunity for voluntary fundraising for bald eagle recovery efforts through a special American Eagle Fund endowment managed by the American Eagle Foundation. Authorization for coins celebrating the bald eagle's recovery and restoration as a symbol of freedom is deemed appropriate. The bald eagle, symbol of freedom in the US, is commemorated for being removed from the endangered species list under the Endangered Species Act of 1973, marking the 35th anniversary of the Act. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins to celebrate the recovery of the bald eagle, America's symbol of freedom, and the 35th anniversary of the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The text chunk discusses the specifications for half dollar clad coins, including the composition, weight, diameter, and minting standards. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the bald eagle and its significance, with inscriptions including the coin's value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated facility of the United States Mint. The Secretary is authorized to issue these coins within a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2008.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in section 7(a), and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be made at a reasonable discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act include surcharges: $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $3 for the half dollar coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the American Eagle Foundation of Tennessee for the care and maintenance of bald eagles and their habitat in the United States. The American Eagle Fund supports various activities such as public education, habitat purchases, raptor rehabilitation, behavior research, and law enforcement for bald eagle protection. It also provides grants for eagle restoration projects within designated regions. The American Eagle Foundation administers the American Eagle Fund, providing financial support for bald eagle restoration and protection projects in Tennessee and the United States. They also support the educational efforts of the foundation. The American Eagle Foundation in Tennessee educates the public nationally about the bald eagle, the national symbol of the United States, through various media channels. They are subject to audit requirements for the funds received.
